title: The Great American Labor Shortage
summary: The $300 weekly subsidy for not working was a terrible blunder.. Businesses nearly everywhere in America say they're desperate for workers, and the latest statistical evidence is the Labor Department's Jolts report Tuesday of a record 9.3 million job openings in April. Get the message, Congress?

title: Internet Conglomerate IAC Is Looking for a New CFO
summary: Finance chief Glenn Schiffman plans to pursue new opportunity after five years in the role. IAC/InterActiveCorp. is searching for a new finance chief after Chief Financial Officer Glenn Schiffman decided to leave the conglomerate to pursue a new opportunity.

title: Millions of J&J Covid-19 Vaccines Are at Risk of Expiring in June
summary: States, hospitals try to reroute such vaccines, while efforts to export them face hurdles. Hospitals, state health departments and the federal government are racing to decide how to use up millions of Johnson & Johnson 's Covid-19 vaccine doses that are set to expire this month.

title: Peru's Leftist Candidate Leads Tight Presidential Vote
summary: Local markets reel as Pedro Castillo holds a small advantage over right-wing opponent Keiko Fujimori with 96% of the votes counted. LIMA, Peru-Pedro Castillo, a far-left political outsider, was leading the count on Tuesday in Peru's tight presidential election as markets reeled over investor concerns he could win and boost state control over the country's market economy.

title: Senate Approves $250 Billion Bill to Boost Tech Research
summary: Legislation seeks to address long-term trends in U.S. competitiveness; it now heads to House after winning bipartisan backing in Senate. WASHINGTON-The Senate on Tuesday approved a bipartisan, $250 billion bill boosting government spending on technology research and development amid rising competition from China and other nations.

title: Lordstown Motors Says It Doesn't Have Cash to Start Commercial Production
summary: The electric-truck startup also says that it has doubts about whether it can continue as a going concern through the end of the year. Electric-truck startup Lordstown Motors Corp. disclosed that it doesn't have sufficient cash to start full commercial production and has doubts about whether it can continue as a going concern through the end of the year.

title: Google Should Be Treated as Utility, Ohio Argues
summary: Latest case adds to legal woes facing the company. Google's critics have said for years that it should be treated like a public utility. On Tuesday, Ohio's attorney general filed a lawsuit asking a judge to rule that the search company is one.

title: SoftBank and IonQ in Strategic Pact on Quantum Computing
summary: The giant Japanese tech investor has taken a large stake in the Maryland start-up to eventually bring quantum-computing power to other SoftBank portfolio companies. The quantum-computing power of IonQ Inc. could eventually be put to work in some of SoftBank Group Corp.'s portfolio companies as part of a recently-announced strategic partnership with the tech investor.

title: Do Your Social Media Profiles Make You Vulnerable to Hacking?
summary: Cybercriminals can build phishing scams based on information gathered from your social profiles. Here's how you can make it harder for them.. You might want to consider taking down the Instagram photo you posted of your first day back at the office post-pandemic. Cybersecurity experts say scammers can glean a lot of information (and quickly) from your social media profiles. The CEO of SocialProof Security, a hacker-led vulnerability-assessment and training firm, says she can find 60% of the information she would need to create a good phishing scheme on Instagram alone in about 30 minutes. When it comes to liking, sharing and posting on social media, here are a few things you might want to hit "delete" on.

title: Return of the IRS Scandal
summary: Someone leaked the tax information of individuals to serve the left's agenda.. That didn't take long. Less than half a year into the Biden Presidency, the Internal Revenue Service is already at the center of an abuse-of-power scandal. That news broke Tuesday when ProPublica, a website whose journalism promotes progressive causes, published information from what it said are 15 years of the tax returns of Jeff Bezos, Warren Buffett and other rich Americans.

title: Mr. Pritzker Breaks His Promise
summary: The Illinois Governor's whopper on redistricting is one for the ages.. J.B. Pritzker didn't say "read my lips" in 2018 when he promised the people of Illinois he wouldn't sign onto a partisan redistricting if elected Governor. Specifically, he promised to veto any redistricting map "drafted or created by legislators, political party leaders and/or their staffs or allies." But on Friday he broke that promise, and it will now take its rightful place in the annals of political whoppers beside George H.W. Bush's famous pledge not to raise taxes.

title: Bitcoin, Ether, Dogecoin Prices Slump as Selloff Picks Up
summary: The cryptocurrencies fell following the Justice Department's recovery of bitcoin from a fuel pipeline hack. Selling in ether and dogecoin accelerated Tuesday, with concerns about heightened government intervention adding to recent pressure on cryptocurrencies.

title: IRS Is Investigating Release of Tax Information of Wealthy Americans
summary: ProPublica published tax, income details of people including Jeff Bezos and Warren Buffett. WASHINGTON-Federal authorities are investigating the release of wealthy Americans' tax information, Internal Revenue Service Commissioner Charles Rettig said Tuesday.

title: FDA Approval of New Alzheimer's Drug May Boost Prospects of Other Treatments
summary: The FDA's reasoning for greenlighting Biogen's Aduhelm could bode well for other Alzheimer's drugs targeting the disease in a similar way. The Food and Drug Administration's approval of Biogen Inc.'s Aduhelm on Monday may have boosted the prospects of other experimental Alzheimer's disease drugs that target the disease in a similar way.

title: Lawmakers' Hypocrisy in Blasting 'Loopholes'
summary: They write exceptions into the tax code, then blame Big Business for them.. We keep hearing that the corporate tax code is riddled with "loopholes" and that large corporations are tax cheats for using them and not paying their "fair share." Is it true? No, most large corporations pay the amount in taxes they do because Congress expressly wrote the tax code to allow them to pay that amount.

title: When Television Went to Bed
summary: One station played 'Taps' when signing off at the end of the broadcast day.. 'Do I amuse you?" Joe Pesci's character said in the 1990 movie "Goodfellas." Today it's a question no one needs to ask. The amusement industry keeps growing. Every second of the day or night, tens of thousands of entertainment options are instantly available on screens that are as common as toothbrushes.

title: 'Anthro-Vision' Review: How to Take the Blinders Off
summary: Trouble follows when insular guilds-bankers, doctors, journalists-fail to take into account the viewpoints and folkways of non-elite people.. When Donald Trump-gaudy and braggadocious-used the word "bigly" in a presidential debate with Hillary Clinton in September 2016, the newsroom of the Financial Times dissolved into merriment. Gillian Tett was there, and she heard herself laugh with the others. The word, she writes, sounded odd. "It was not the type of 'proper' English of the sort that presidents were supposed to use or that journalists employed every day."

title: 'Meme' Stocks Can Learn From AMC
summary: A CEO rightly focuses on meeting the public's irrational desire for his shares.. Stock investors are free to buy for any reason they want (except inside information) and yet it works better for society if they buy and sell depending on whether a company appears to be cheap in relation to long-term prospects. This sends the right message to managers. It directs capital to its most highly valued uses. It makes the world safe for indexers.

title: The FBI Secretly Ran a Messaging Platform, Yielding Hundreds of Arrests
summary: Monitoring of encrypted communications yielded over 800 arrests in 16 countries of suspected members of crime networks. Hundreds of suspected members of criminal networks have been arrested by authorities around the world after being duped into using an encrypted communications platform secretly run by the FBI to hatch their plans for alleged crimes including drug smuggling and money laundering.

title: What Drives GOP Resistance to Vaccines?
summary: Eight in 10 Democrats have at least one dose, compared with about half of Republicans.. As public concern about the pandemic continues to decline, the Biden administration is pushing hard to meet its goal of vaccinating 70% of adults with at least one shot by the Fourth of July. More than 60% of the country is already vaccinated.

title: The Democrats' Problem Isn't Joe Manchin
summary: They should be worried about the increasing appeal of conservatism to minority voters.. Political progressives are infuriated with Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin of West Virginia for insisting on bipartisanship at a time when the country is sharply divided, Democrats control the House by a whisker, and the Senate is split 50-50. The nerve of this guy!

title: Western Michigan University Gets Largest Donation Ever for Public University
summary: An unnamed group of alumni give $550 million, more than doubling the school's endowment. Western Michigan University has received a $550 million gift from a group of alumni, a record for a public university that more than doubles the school's endowment.

title: Tribeca Festival Drops Film From Name in New Entertainment Era
summary: New York's biggest film event embraces podcasting along with interactive mediums like gaming and virtual reality.

title: Manhattan Bakery Accuses Grubhub, DoorDash, Uber Eats of Illegal Fees
summary: A lawsuit says the ordering and delivery platforms levy charges beyond what New York City law allows. A company behind a Manhattan bakery has filed a proposed class-action lawsuit against major third-party ordering and delivery platforms, including Grubhub Inc., DoorDash Inc. and Uber Eats, saying they have billed it and other food businesses more than allowed by New York City law.

title: Internet Outage Hits Major Websites
summary: Hourlong disruption affected sites including New York Times, U.K. government portal; cloud-services provider Fastly reports internal problem. Dozens of websites in the U.S. and Europe briefly went dark Tuesday, victims of an internal glitch at a major cloud-service provider and the latest example of how a problem at a single player in the internet's piping can have outsize repercussions.

title: Democrats Consider Changes to Voting Bill Amid Manchin Opposition
summary: Pivotal centrist senator from West Virginia opposes current version of election overhaul proposal. WASHINGTON-Senate Democrats said they were considering changes to their election overhaul proposal, after pivotal centrist Sen. Joe Manchin made clear he opposed both the current bill and any imminent move to weaken Republicans' power to block legislation.

title: U.S. Stocks Finish in Mixed Territory
summary: Nasdaq Composite rose slightly as S&P 500 was about flat. The S&P 500 ended slightly higher Tuesday, pushing the index to its third-highest close on record, after a trading day marked by narrow swings between gains and losses.

title: 'The Human Condition' Review: A Japanese Epic in High-Def
summary: The 9-and-a-half-hour film, set in wartime Japan, gets a digital restoration from the Criterion Collection that underscores its tragic dimensions.

title: 'Moloch' Review: Up in Flames
summary: In this six-part French thriller, a journalist and a psychiatrist team up to investigate a series of human combustions. Watching the six-part, French-made psychological thriller "Moloch," I kept thinking about "The Book of Lists" by David Wallechinsky, Irving Wallace and Amy Wallace, a compendium of esoterica first published in 1977 and the ancestor of internet searches and listicles. Among its cataloging of bizarre phenomena, opinions and obscure facts (the worst movies ever, the world's best reference works, celebrities who died during sex, various people suspected of being Jack the Ripper) was a list that always stuck with me: eight instances of spontaneous human combustion. People who apparently just burst into flames. As they do in "Moloch."

title: Meme Stocks Turn Options Market Upside Down
summary: Flurry of activity in meme-stock options underscores investors' fear of missing out on surges. The meteoric rally in meme stocks such as AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. and GameStop Corp. has unleashed a burst of options trading, upending traditional dynamics in the market for stock bets.

title: Wisconsin Pharmacist Sentenced to Three Years in Prison for Tampering With Covid Vaccines
summary: Steven Brandenburg, a vaccine skeptic, said he tampered with 500 doses of the Moderna vaccine. A federal judge on Tuesday sentenced Wisconsin pharmacist Steven Brandenburg to three years in prison for intentionally trying to spoil hundreds of Covid-19 vaccines last year.

title: Vogtle Nuclear Plant in Georgia Faces More Construction Delays
summary: Southern Co. project is only one of its type in U.S., and could cost $2 billion more than expected. The only nuclear-power plant under construction in the U.S. is facing delays and additional costs. Again.

title: The American Jobs (Reduction) Plan
summary: Another analysis finds economic destruction in the Biden 'infrastructure' agenda.. Senate Republicans have been trying to persuade President Joe Biden to accept a scaled-down version of his new spending plans. Given the tax hikes he intends to go along with them, a new report suggests that scaling the Biden "infrastructure" plan down to zero might be the best outcome for U.S. workers. The Tax Foundation reports the results of its analysis:

title: Closed CASE (Wednesday Crossword, June 9)
Renault Charged in France in Emissions Fraud Probe
summary: Auto maker denies wrongdoing, says its vehicles aren't equipped with rigging software. French prosecutors on Tuesday brought preliminary charges against Renault SA on suspicion of emissions fraud, adding to the fallout for auto makers following Volkswagen AG's emission scandal.

title: At J&J, Some 15.5 Billion Potential Cyberattacks Each Day
summary: The company's chief information security officer talks about where the threats are coming from. Covid-19 vaccines have transformed the global economy. The companies that produce them, meanwhile, already a big target for hackers, have to be more on their toes than ever.

title: California D.A. Seeks U.S. Agencies' Information on San Jose Shooter
summary: Local official says sharing about U.S. questioning of Samuel Cassidy in 2016 would aid investigation into shooting that killed nine. A California district attorney said federal authorities hadn't provided any information they gathered five years ago about the man who killed nine people at his San Jose workplace May 26, calling the lack of intelligence sharing an issue of public safety.

title: Infinity Q Capital Management Plans to Return $500 Million to Mutual-Fund Investors
summary: How much investors will eventually recoup from its Diversified Alpha Fund remains unclear. Infinity Q Capital Management says it plans to return approximately $500 million to investors who were unable to get their money back after the investment firm halted redemptions on a then-$1.7 billion mutual fund earlier this year.

title: Readers Debate Gas, Oil and Electric Heat
summary: In 30 years at my home, I have lost electric power nearly 100 times, sometimes for days including after superstorm Sandy, while I cannot remember losing natural gas once.. "Cities, States Wage Battle Over Banning Gas in Homes" (Page One, June 1) raises the prospect that policies aimed at reducing carbon emissions will lead to stranded gas assets and higher costs for remaining gas customers. The fear is that as more ratepayers switch to cleaner options than natural gas, the small number of ratepayers who remain will have to shoulder the cost of the entire gas system. It doesn't have to be that way, however, if gas utilities are given a role to play in a future of clean heating and cooling.

title: Rural, Green Wind Power Has Its Drawbacks
summary: Communities seldom know what they are accepting.. Regarding the May 25 letter from the American Clean Power Association's CEO Heather Zichal: Communities seldom know what they are accepting. As an energy-law attorney in upstate New York, I have reviewed many wind-turbine leases presented to landowners. Every one of them contained a confidentiality clause that would make the CIA proud. Typically the lease bars the landowner from disclosing anything about the lease. These clauses are anticompetitive, intimidating (injunctive relief and attorney fees) and entirely one-sided. They prevent landowners from discussing rents and other lease terms with other landowners, municipal officials and the press, effectively trapping the landowner in a take-it-or-leave-it black box of silence and ignorance.

title: Jobs: If Only Government Would Get Out of the Way
summary: The government can improve labor-force participation by getting out of the way, and cutting back on paying people not to work.. William A. Galston points out that government can increase productivity by improving labor-force participation ("Biden's Slow-Growth Budget Gamble," Politics & Ideas, June 2). He says this can be done by easing the way into the labor force for women, the formerly incarcerated, young adults not headed for college and immigrants. By and large, those measures require the government to do more. It can also improve labor-force participation by getting out of the way, and cutting back on paying people not to work.

title: U.S. Embassies Should Fly Only America's Flag
summary: I abhor the instructions from the State Department encouraging our embassies and consulates to fly the Black Lives Matters flags.. Regarding Dave Seminara's "Diplomats Abase America" (op-ed, June 1): As a former senior foreign service officer with over 35 years of service, including as a naval officer and, more important, as a citizen of the U.S., I abhor the instructions from the State Department encouraging our embassies and consulates to fly the Black Lives Matters flag. The only flag that should ever fly over our diplomatic posts is the one that represents all of us, the American flag.

title: U.S. Threatens to Sue Texas Over Shelters for Immigrant Children
summary: The move is in response to Texas Gov. Greg Abbott's order to end licensing for such facilities. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration Monday threatened to sue Texas over an order from its governor to pull state licenses from shelters that house unaccompanied immigrant children.

title: Ship Orders Surge as Carriers Rush to Add Capacity
summary: Big shipyards say they are running out of construction slots and they are raising prices to meet rising steel costs. Global shipyards that were retrenching and consolidating in a faltering maritime market barely more than a year ago are now flush with new orders, boosted by efforts by shipping lines to add capacity to meet resurgent consumer demand in Western economies.

title: The Importance of Holding a Memorial-Readers Respond
summary: An article about funerals delayed by Covid struck a chord; 'In the end, it's about getting together to remember loved ones'. The pandemic changed everything about life, and death, in the last year. Amid the chaos and quarantine, people across the nation were unable to honor their loved ones at traditional funerals.

title: Biden Administration Outlines Measures to Address Supply-Chain Issues
summary: Action follows 100-day review of the breakdown of supply chains during the pandemic. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration outlined new measures Tuesday to address widespread supply-chain issues, with a goal of bringing manufacturing back to the U.S. and diversifying access to foreign-made materials such as rare-earth minerals used for batteries.

title: The Scottish EPA Was Hacked. Here's What Happened Next.
summary: The agency's CEO talks about how he and his colleagues responded to the attack last December-and what lessons they have learned. On Christmas Eve 2020, the Scottish Environment Protection Agency received a most unwelcome visitor: Hackers took control of its computer systems, seized data and demanded a ransom.

title: Clover Health's Stock Price Surges After Becoming New Reddit Darling
summary: Individual investors are targeting the SPAC-listed company, hoping it catches similar momentum to AMC and GameStop. Shares of Clover Health Investments Corp. soared after emerging as the latest target for retail traders on Reddit forums.

title: French President Emmanuel Macron Appears to Get Slapped in Video
summary: Two men were immediately detained by police, a spokesman for the Interior Ministry says. PARIS-A man appeared to slap French President Emmanuel Macron across the face Tuesday during a visit to a small town in southern France, in a sign of how tensions are building ahead of next year's presidential election.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Narrowed in April
summary: Slowdown in consumer spending contributes to drop in imports in April. WASHINGTON-The U.S. trade deficit narrowed in April from a record level in March as disruptions in global supply chains and a slowdown in consumer spending contributed to a drop in imports.

title: U.K. Police Officer Pleads Guilty to Kidnap and Rape in Woman's Death
summary: Marketing executive's murder earlier this year in London sparked protests over violence toward women. LONDON-A British police officer pleaded guilty Tuesday to the kidnap and rape of Sarah Everard, a marketing executive whose murder earlier this year in London sparked protests over violence toward women.

title: Bipartisan Probe Faults Intelligence, Security Failures Over Jan. 6 Riot
summary: Bipartisan report recommends making it easier for the Capitol Police chief to request National Guard assistance, among other actions. A bipartisan Senate report faulted Capitol security officials as well as federal agencies for intelligence and planning failures leading up to the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, and recommended that the Capitol Police chief be able to unilaterally request help from the National Guard in an emergency.

title: For the Economy, Quitting Never Felt So Good
summary: People are quitting their jobs like never before. That could be a long-run positive.. Employers aren't only struggling to hire new workers, they look as if they are having a hard time hanging onto the workers they already have.

title: The FBI's Advice on Ransomware: Don't Pay, but Tell Us if You Do
summary: A deputy assistant director also asks companies to make sure they report breaches. Companies have come under increasing attacks by cybercriminals in the past year, due in part to the pandemic. The Federal Bureau of Investigation, meanwhile, is asking for the U.S. business community's help in stopping these costly crimes.

title: The Power of Natural Immunity
summary: Studies show it's durable and widespread. If you've had Covid, you can get by with one shot of vaccine.. The news about the U.S. Covid pandemic is even better than you've heard. Some 80% to 85% of American adults are immune to the virus: More than 64% have received at least one vaccine dose and, of those who haven't, roughly half have natural immunity from prior infection. There's ample scientific evidence that natural immunity is effective and durable, and public-health leaders should pay it heed.

title: Schoolyard Justice in Federal Court
summary: Citibank's errant billion-dollar payment leads to a ruling that could upset commercial law.. 'Finders keepers, losers weepers" is something you expect to hear in a schoolyard, not a courtroom. But a federal judge effectively delivered that message to Citibank recently. The bank administered a loan of some $1 billion, sending payments from Revlon to the lenders. Citibank mistakenly sent a wire transfer of the entire principal amount due when it only intended a single installment.

title: Colonial Pipeline's Recovery From Hack Not Yet Complete
summary: CEO Joseph Blount also tells lawmakers that paying ransom to hackers was the right decision. WASHINGTON-The pipeline company hit by a multimillion-dollar ransomware attack last month is still working to fully restore some of its computer systems, its chief executive told lawmakers Tuesday, as he defended his decision to pay hackers a ransom.

title: One Oil Company's Rocky Path to Renewable Energy
summary: Resume Subscription. For years, Danish Oil and Natural Gas Co. did what many other big oil companies do: pumped hydrocarbons out of the North Sea.

title: Fishing in the Outer Banks-a Living Piece of Maritime History
summary: Angling off North Carolina's Hatteras Island isn't a lazy man's sport. The oldest fishing charter in the region regularly delivers the thrill of the hunt.. CAPTAIN BRYAN Mattingly showed me how to stand. Shoulders upright, knees bent, core tight. He wanted me to smile, too. I found this hard to do while perched atop the cabin at the narrow bow of the Albatross-a 43-foot-long, prewar fishing boat. We were just off the coast of Hatteras Island, N.C. Nothing secured me to the bow except my own two feet. If I stumbled while casting a fishing rod that was twice my height, I'd plunge into the cold, green Atlantic Ocean, where I was certain sharks circled below the surface.

title: For Some, Built-to-Rent Communities Make Buying vs. Renting a No-Brainer
summary: These people can afford to buy a home, but instead are opting for built-to-rent communities that include an array of luxury amenities. After selling her family's four-bedroom home in Atlanta and moving to Arizona for her husband's job relocation, Gabrielle Brand toured single-family houses and condominiums, looking for a home for herself, her husband, Trevor Brand, and their 2-year-old daughter. The couple decided on a brand new, four-bedroom, 3½-bath home in Litchfield Park, a suburb of Phoenix. But instead of buying it, they are renting.

title: London Metal Exchange Pedals Back on Closing Trading Ring
summary: Exchange will reopen storied open-outcry ring in September after members protested against plans to close the pit permanently. The London Metal Exchange will reopen its open-outcry trading ring in September, halting plans to close a pit that dates back to the industrial revolution following resistance from an influential group of traders.

title: Covid-19 Vaccines for Young Children Move Ahead in Testing
summary: Pfizer and BioNTech begin testing shot in children under 12, while Moderna aims for results from testing in kids 5 years and older in fall. Covid-19 vaccines from Pfizer Inc. and Moderna Inc. are edging closer to use in young children.

title: A Herd of Wild Elephants Wandering Across China Captivates Millions
summary: Resume Subscription. China's latest social-media stars are large, riding a sugar high and destroying everything in their path. They may also need a map.

title: Job Openings Reached Record Level This Spring
summary: Government and private-sector data show surge in demand for workers led by leisure and hospitality industries. Available jobs in the U.S. climbed further above pre-pandemic levels last month following a record surge earlier in the spring, a sign of strong demand for workers-with leisure and hospitality sectors showing the most growth in openings.

title: Before He Joined the Brat Pack, Andrew McCarthy's Acting Career 'Began as an Accident'
summary: Resume Subscription. Andrew McCarthy, 58, is an actor and director best known for starring roles in "St. Elmo's Fire," "Weekend at Bernie's" and "Less Than Zero." He is the author of the memoir "Brat: An '80s Story" (Grand Central). He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Why the Hybrid Workplace Is a Cybersecurity Nightmare
summary: It's a hacker's dream: a constantly changing mix of office and remote workers, devices that move in and out of the company networks, and security staffs stretched thin. For many bosses and employees, there is a measure of relief in returning to the office-especially for those who have the flexibility of continuing to work from home part of the time. But for those teams working to protect their offices from hackers, the new hybrid workplaces aren't nearly as welcome.

title: What We Know About the G-7's Global Corporate Tax Proposal
summary: Rewriting the rules on how major companies are taxed could have broad repercussions-depending on how the details play out. Seven wealthy countries have announced a plan to impose a minimum levy on multinational corporations and rewrite the rules governing how countries tax them, but policy makers around the world will need to make some tough choices before anything actually changes.

title: Father's Day 2021: Gifts for the Beach and the Backyard
summary: From a foldable kayak to a Grateful Dead-themed cooler, 12 of the best gifts to help Dad relax by the water-or on the lawn-this summer. MAYBE HE'S a seasoned fisherman or a burgeoning kayaker. Maybe he's most content sitting in the sun on the beach, blasting the Grateful Dead from a Bluetooth speaker. Or perhaps he plans to spend the summer in a backyard lawn chair eyeing the kids as they splash around in the inflatable pool, occasionally drenching him. No matter his preferred summer pastime, odds are the dad in your life could benefit from some time spent by the water this Father's Day. Below, 12 of our picks for helping him do just that, from a fishing-equipment subscription box to a solar-powered diving watch worn by Arnold Schwarzenegger.

title: Big Lots Invests in New Stores as Stimulus Checks Boost Sales
summary: CFO Jonathan Ramsden says the company plans to add new locations and distribution centers. Discount retailer Big Lots Inc. is investing in new stores and distribution centers as it capitalizes on higher sales driven by federal stimulus checks and the recent home-improvement craze.

title: Big Banks Face Climate-Change Tests
summary: Bank of England will measure the resilience of U.K. banks and insurers under three climate-change scenarios. The Bank of England launched a program to assess the ability of lenders and insurers to withstand risks such as rising sea levels, flooding, cyclones and wildfires, in the latest step by a central bank to scrutinize the impact of climate change.

title: How Does Unemployment Work?
summary: Where to Find Your State's Unemployment Benefits. Millions of Americans have found themselves out of work during the coronavirus pandemic, but there are options to help you get back on your feet. If you recently received a termination notice from your company, you may be able to negotiate a severance package to help you as you look for your next job. If you are struggling to find work, you could look into whether you are eligible for unemployment insurance, which can provide you with extra money while you search for a job.

title: Recent Spate of Mass Shootings Is Among Worst in U.S. History
summary: Five attacks, in which 39 were killed as U.S. re-opened from the pandemic, followed year that saw no such events. A string of mass shootings over the past three months as the U.S. re-opened from the pandemic was one of the worst on record, and law-enforcement officials are fearful of more to come.

title: Coco Gauff Is America's Unlikely Clay-Court Star
summary: The 17-year-old is making her deepest run yet at a Grand Slam tournament by showing a taste for the red clay of Roland-Garros. PARIS-In putting together the deepest major tournament run of her young career, Coco Gauff has been on court for less than five hours in total. She has reached the French Open quarterfinals by powering through three victories and a walkover. And by now, she has spent more time in Paris engaged in daily games of UNO with her parents than playing in tennis matches.

title: Are You Over Zoom Meetings, Too? Let's Talk
summary: People who clung to video chats with friends and family during the pandemic are shunning virtual meetings as real-life encounters resume. Have you dumped your Zoom group yet? If not, it's probably only a matter of time.

title: How to Steer Clear of Pricey Car Rentals This Summer
summary: Resume Subscription. The national car-rental chains have had a truly roller-coaster year. They sold off their fleets when pandemic business plunged, then got caught short when demand returned faster than expected. Now, spurred by the shortage, they've hiked prices sky high-with weekend rates for standard-size cars in New York City often exceeding $180 a day.

title: Sarah Feinberg Tapped to Lead New York's MTA
summary: Ms. Feinberg would be the first woman to head the nation's largest transit agency; Janno Lieber will be appointed as the agency's chief executive. Sarah Feinberg, a transportation leader who steered New York City's subway through the Covid-19 pandemic, is set to be nominated as the first woman to lead New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, according to a senior MTA official.

title: Ford's Maverick Truck Offers Alternative to Huge Pickups
summary: Auto maker reveals smaller model, coming this fall, to attract buyers who want a flatbed but don't have the money or space for a big truck. Pickup trucks in the U.S. have trended for years toward the bigger, brawnier and more expensive. Now, Ford Motor Co. is reversing course, with plans to sell a diminutive hybrid truck with a price tag-and gas mileage-similar to that of a compact car.

title: Wealth Gap Likely to Widen as Major Economies Power Recovery, World Bank Says
summary: Bank projects fastest economic rebound in 80 years, but uneven vaccine distribution is hurting low-income countries. WASHINGTON-Global inequality is likely to widen this year as a small number of major economies power the fastest recovery in 80 years while many poorer countries struggle to return to pre-pandemic income levels, the World Bank said.

title: New Israeli Coalition Government Set to Be Sworn In Sunday
summary: Embattled Netanyahu waging last minute effort to scuttle the coalition. TEL AVIV-An eight-party coalition aimed at unseating Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is set to be sworn in on Sunday, as a key right-wing lawmaker rebuffed the embattled leader's overtures to defect from the new government.

title: What Hackers Can Learn About You From Your Social-Media Profile
summary: That post you 'liked' on Facebook? Your alma mater on LinkedIn? They are all clues that can make you-and your company-vulnerable.. That cute photo of your fluffy Lagotto Romagnolo on Instagram. The TikTok video of your team finally back together in the office. An alma mater highlighted on your LinkedIn page.

title: Biden's Capital-Gains Tax Proposal Puts Estate Planners to Work
summary: The plan would raise rates on the wealthy and tax gains at death; Congress may have different ideas. Estate planners for the wealthiest Americans are combing through the Biden administration's proposed tax increases, hunting for ways to sidestep the potential hit from higher taxes on investment income and new capital-gains taxes at death.

title: Clover Health, Stitch Fix, Coupa Software: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Stock futures wavered, extending a pattern of muted moves ahead of data on job openings. U.S. stock futures drifted higher, suggesting major indexes would turn in a mixed performance after the opening bell in an extension of the recent choppy but range-bound trading.

title: What Is Your Microbiome? A Wellness Trend Taking On Post-Covid Urgency
summary: Probiotics aren't just good for your gut: How hyping "good" bacteria can boost immunity and protect your skin. Call it a sign of the times: Microbiomes-the network of bacteria, fungi, viruses and other microorganisms (or microbiota) that our bodies play host to-have been getting more attention of late. Though they're known for aiding digestion, their role in healthy immune function may be what's currently boosting their reputation. "With the emergence of Covid, we're all becoming aware of just how important it [the microbiome] is," says New York-based dermatologist Whitney Bowe. A recent study by the Chinese University in Hong Kong that compared data from 27 recovering Covid-19 patients to healthy samples found that microbiome imbalance was linked to the severity and length of Covid cases. (Those with Covid lacked certain types of good bacteria.) Researchers at the University of Connecticut are continuing to examine the link between the Covid vaccine and the microbiome.

title: Ferrari Brings Back Its Legendary Trattoria With Chef Massimo Bottura
summary: The Italian car company opens Cavallino, a reimagining of the iconic restaurant in Emilia-Romagna by chef Massimo Bottura and designer India Mahdavi. Enzo Ferrari, the founder of the Ferrari sports car brand and Formula 1 racing team, was a disciplined man who liked his routines. The former race car driver turned Italian industrialist rarely left his home region of Emilia-Romagna. Most days you could set your watch by his arrival for lunch at Ristorante Cavallino, a modest company-owned trattoria across from the Ferrari factory in Maranello, named for the prancing horse logo on the cars he produced.

title: Brits Queue Up for New Wendy's
summary: Brands with expansion plans benefit from glut of available sites. Wendy's Co. is returning to the U.K. two decades after it left, part of an American fast-food-chain invasion that has been a rare bright spot for restaurant property owners during the pandemic.

title: Life-Sciences Boom Puts Boston Property Ahead of the Pack
summary: Venture capitalists pumped $7.2 billion into life-sciences companies in Boston through May. Boston's office market has become the envy of landlords across the country, thanks to its expanding biotech and other life-sciences companies awash in capital.

title: A Modular Hotel Is Going Up in Manhattan, if the Rooms Ever Leave Brooklyn
summary: The ambitious modular hotel's future now looks uncertain. The world's tallest modular-construction hotel was created to rise 26 stories over Manhattan. The guest rooms were built in a Polish factory and arrived fully finished in New York, where they would be stacked in a matter of weeks.

title: Berkshire Hathaway to Buy $500 Million Stake in Brazil's Nubank
summary: Deal values Brazil's largest digital bank at $30 billion. Brazil's digital bank operator Nu Pagamentos SA said Berkshire Hathaway Inc. agreed to buy $500 million of its shares, as digital banking expands quickly in Latin America's largest economy.

title: AMC's Meme-Stock Traders Mess With Corporate Theory
summary: Neither shareholder value nor stakeholder value explains selling shares into a wild froth. The theory of the firm features a thriving academic debate about whether responsibility to shareholders or responsibility to broader stakeholders should be the founding principle of corporate life.

title: Tesla's China Sales Bounce Back Despite Consumer Backlash
summary: Elon Musk's EV maker has been hit by bad publicity in China over its handling of customer complaints and perceived quality problems. SHANGHAI- Tesla Inc.'s sales in China rebounded in May after a short slump, a boost for the electric-vehicle maker as it looks to overcome its first major stumble in one of its most important markets.

title: Stitch Fix Works Its Makeover
summary: If you're an investor, retail trends may matter almost as much as financials this year. Consumers want to wear real clothes again, but they have apparently forgotten how to dress themselves-presenting a big opportunity for Stitch Fix, which is already enjoying the spoils of sweatpants fatigue.

title: Citigroup's Long Trip Home
summary: An exit from some global retail markets and a focus on wealth are moves investors should watch closely. Under new management, Citigroup is still aiming to close its performance gap to peers. But how it goes about that may be changing.

title: Is the Dollar's Long Slide Coming to an End?
summary: Recovery-related forces that have pushed the greenback down over the past year may be almost spent. The "reopening trade" has posed a real challenge to King Dollar, but there could be a limit to how much power this monarchy is willing to give back.

title: The Pandemic's Legacy of Financial Frailty in Emerging Markets
summary: Critics of public debt accumulation usually mean well, but in many cases the alternative is steeper borrowing by individuals and companies. Debt levels rose in almost every corner of the world last year, but how the burden is shared between governments and the private sector varies widely. Some countries may come to wish the mix of borrowers was a little different.

title: U.S. to Launch Trade Talks With Taiwan
summary: Effort to revive dormant trade and investment framework risks aggravating tensions with China. The Biden administration is launching trade and investment talks with Taiwan, advancing U.S. ties with Taipei and likely adding to frictions with the island's nemesis, Beijing.

title: Who Could Cancel the Tokyo Olympics?
summary: A final decision about the Games is a high-stakes game of chicken between Japan and the International Olympic Committee. The Japanese government may have leverage.. The intensity of the standoff between International Olympic Committee officials and the Japanese public over whether this summer's Tokyo Games should go on as planned was clear recently when IOC member Dick Pound told a magazine that the event would take place even if Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga asked that it be canceled.

title: Mining Companies Call Themselves Green in Push for Investor Cash
summary: Many tout their production of materials that go into wind turbines, power lines and batteries. Mining companies are trying to tap into the flood of cash targeting green investments by touting their production of materials that go into wind turbines, power lines and batteries.

title: A Commodities Crunch Caused by Stingy Capital Spending Has No Quick Fix
summary: Limited inventory of resources is converging with a buying spree to supercharge prices, spurring inflation concerns. HONG KONG-A yearlong steep climb in commodity prices is testing an economics maxim: High prices cure themselves by spurring supply and quenching demand.

title: Russia Puts the Squeeze on Social Media to Police Its Critics
summary: Kremlin uses Twitter and other platforms to advance its goals overseas, but is now trying to prevent its opponents from using the same tools. MOSCOW-Russia's government was quick to use social media when it tried to steer the course of U.S. elections, American officials say. It isn't quite as eager to see its own opponents at home try the same thing.

title: Derby's Take: Fed Is Fine With Reverse Repos Nearing Half a Trillion
summary: Resume Subscription. A once obscure Federal Reserve rate control facility is now holding nearly half a trillion dollars day after day, and the New York Fed's leader isn't concerned.

title: European Energy Sector Prepares for New Cybersecurity Rules
summary: Colonial Pipeline attack showed the exposure of critical infrastructure to hackers. The ransomware attack on Colonial Pipeline Co. last month ignited concerns about cybersecurity in Europe, where lawmakers are drafting laws that will apply to energy firms and other critical infrastructure.

title: DOJ to Defend Trump in Lawsuit Over Rape Claim
summary: Journalist E. Jean Carroll sued former president for defamation after he denied raping her in the 1990s. The Justice Department will move forward with its defense of former President Donald Trump in a defamation suit brought by a journalist over allegations that the former president raped her in the 1990s.

title: Report Finds It Plausible Covid-19 Leaked From Lab
summary: The 2020 lab report was used by the State Department in its own inquiry during Trump administration. WASHINGTON-A report on the origins of Covid-19 by a U.S. government national laboratory concluded that the hypothesis claiming the virus leaked from a Chinese lab in Wuhan is plausible and deserves further investigation, according to people familiar with the classified document.

title: Bain Capital and Crosspoint Capital Partners Buy ExtraHop Networks
summary: The investment in the network detection and response services software provider comes amid multiple recent ransomware and hacking incidents. Two private-equity firms are buying cybersecurity company ExtraHop Networks Inc. for $900 million, as a series of recent high-profile ransomware attacks have put cybersecurity risk back in the spotlight.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Peru's Presidential Election Is Still Too Close to Call
summary: Leftist candidate Pedro Castillo widens razor-thin lead over right-wing candidate Keiko Fujimori. LIMA, Peru-Peru's leftist presidential candidate Pedro Castillo widened his razor-thin lead on Monday after a divisive runoff election against right-wing candidate Keiko Fujimori, who alleged fraud without providing proof.

title: New York City Law Department Hit by Cyberattack
summary: Hackers breached computer system over the weekend. Hackers breached the New York City Law Department's computer system over the weekend, prompting the city to limit access to the network as it investigates the cyberattack, officials said Monday.

title: U.S. Mandates Body Cameras for Federal Law-Enforcement
summary: Justice Department reverses longtime policy as more local police forces require video monitoring of police actions. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department will require federal agents to wear body cameras when executing arrest warrants or searching buildings, Deputy Attorney General Lisa Monaco said Monday, reversing a longstanding federal policy as more local police agencies mandate the devices for accountability.
